categories.title: Historical Avant-Garde (1850-1940)
categories.description: Foundational movements establishing modern design principles

themes.name: Arts and Crafts Movement
themes.historicalContext: Founded by William Morris (1860-1910). Reaction against industrialization emphasizing craftsmanship.
themes.tagline: Honest craftsmanship in the machine age

themes.name: Art Nouveau
themes.historicalContext: International movement (1890-1910) characterized by organic forms

themes.name: Bauhaus
themes.historicalContext: German school (1919-1933) founded by Walter Gropius unifying arts/crafts
themes.tagline: Form follows function in the machine age

themes.name: De Stijl
themes.historicalContext: Dutch movement (1917-1931) founded by Theo van Doesburg

themes.name: Constructivism
themes.historicalContext: Russian movement (1913-1940s) merging art with industrial production
themes.tagline: Art as a tool for revolutionary change

themes.name: Futurism
themes.historicalContext: Italian avant-garde movement (1909-1944) celebrating technology/speed
themes.tagline: Capturing the speed and violence of modernity

themes.name: Dada
themes.historicalContext: Anti-art movement (1916-1924) reacting to WWI through absurdity

themes.name: Art Deco
themes.historicalContext: Global style (1920-1939) representing luxury/modernity

themes.name: Vienna Secession
themes.historicalContext: Austrian movement (1897-1905) breaking from academic art
themes.tagline: To every age its art, to art its freedom

themes.name: Suprematism
themes.historicalContext: Russian abstract art movement (1915-1930s) founded by Malevich
themes.tagline: The supremacy of pure artistic feeling

themes.name: Expressionism
themes.historicalContext: Germanic art movement (1905-1933) emphasizing subjective emotion

themes.name: Streamline Moderne
themes.historicalContext: Late Art Deco phase (1930-1950) emphasizing aerodynamic forms

themes.name: Cubism
themes.historicalContext: Revolutionary art movement (1907-1914) pioneered by Picasso/Braque

themes.name: Fauvism
themes.historicalContext: Early 20th-century movement (1904-1908) emphasizing painterly qualities

themes.name: Der Blaue Reiter
themes.historicalContext: German expressionist group (1911-1914) co-founded by Kandinsky
themes.tagline: The spiritual in art through symbolic form

categories.title: Mid-Century Modern (1945-1970)
categories.description: Post-war design emphasizing organic forms, new materials, and space-age optimism

themes.name: Organic Modernism
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by Alvar Aalto and Charles Eames (1945-1965). Blended natural forms with industrial production.

themes.name: International Typographic Style
themes.historicalContext: Developed in Switzerland (1950s) by Müller-Brockmann and Hofmann. Grid-based precision.
themes.tagline: Precision and clarity through grid systems

themes.name: Googie Architecture
themes.historicalContext: American space-age style (1950-1970) for coffee shops and motels. Popularized by John Lautner.
themes.tagline: Space-age optimism for the jet set

themes.name: Space Age Design
themes.historicalContext: Atomic Era aesthetic (1955-1975) influenced by Sputnik and NASA missions.
themes.tagline: Design for the atomic era and beyond

themes.name: Danish Modern
themes.historicalContext: Scandinavian design movement (1945-1970) led by Hans Wegner and Arne Jacobsen.

themes.name: Populuxe
themes.historicalContext: American consumer aesthetic (1954-1964) blending luxury and accessibility.
themes.tagline: Luxury for the masses in the atomic age

themes.name: Brutalist Architecture
themes.historicalContext: Post-war architectural movement (1950-1975) emphasizing raw materials. Pioneered by Le Corbusier.

themes.name: Tiki Culture
themes.historicalContext: American Polynesian-inspired aesthetic (1930-1970) popularized by Don the Beachcomber.

themes.name: Metabolist Movement
themes.historicalContext: Japanese architectural movement (1959-1970) envisioning organic urban growth. Led by Kenzo Tange.
themes.tagline: Cities that grow like living organisms

themes.name: California Design Movement
themes.historicalContext: West Coast aesthetic (1945-1975) blending craft and industry. Championed by the Eameses.

themes.name: Space Race Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: NASA-inspired design (1957-1975) reflecting Cold War technological competition.

themes.name: Atomic Age Design
themes.historicalContext: Post-WWII aesthetic (1945-1965) celebrating nuclear energy and scientific progress.

themes.name: Scandinavian Design
themes.historicalContext: Nordic design philosophy (1930-1970) emphasizing functionality and nature. Led by Marimekko.
themes.tagline: Functional beauty inspired by Nordic landscapes

themes.name: Italian Modernism
themes.historicalContext: Post-war Italian design (1945-1975) combining craftsmanship and industry. Led by Gio Ponti.

themes.name: Japanese Postwar Design
themes.historicalContext: Reconstruction-era design (1945-1970) blending tradition and modernity. Led by Ikko Tanaka.
themes.tagline: Modern design rooted in Japanese tradition

themes.name: Corporate Modernism
themes.historicalContext: Post-war business aesthetic (1950-1970) developed by design firms like Chermayeff & Geismar.

themes.name: High-Tech Architecture
themes.historicalContext: Late modernist movement (1960-1980) celebrating structural expression. Pioneered by Norman Foster.

categories.title: Postmodern & Late 20th Century (1970-2000)
categories.description: Reactions against modernism embracing complexity, reference, and irony

themes.name: Memphis Group
themes.historicalContext: Founded by Ettore Sottsass in Milan (1981). Rebelled against modernist minimalism with playful geometries.
themes.tagline: Radical irreverence in form and color

themes.name: New Wave Typography
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by Wolfgang Weingart (1970s). Broke Swiss typographic grids with experimental layouts.

themes.name: Punk Design
themes.historicalContext: Emerging from 1970s UK music scene. DIY aesthetic challenging establishment norms.
themes.tagline: Destroy the establishment with scissors and glue

themes.name: Deconstructivism
themes.historicalContext: Architectural movement (1980s) led by Zaha Hadid and Peter Eisenman. Fragmented forms.
themes.tagline: Architecture at the edge of chaos

themes.name: High-Tech Architecture
themes.historicalContext: Late modernist movement (1970-1990) celebrating structural expression. Norman Foster/Renzo Piano.

themes.name: Anti-Design
themes.historicalContext: Italian movement (1970s) rejecting functionalism. Led by Superstudio and Archizoom.

themes.name: Radical Design
themes.historicalContext: Italian avant-garde (1960s-1970s) merging architecture with social critique.
themes.tagline: Design as a weapon for social change

themes.name: Transavantgarde
themes.historicalContext: Italian art movement (1979) bridging avant-garde and traditional painting.

themes.name: Neo-Expressionism
themes.historicalContext: Global art movement (1970s-1980s) reviving emotional, figurative painting.
themes.tagline: The return of emotion to contemporary art

themes.name: Memphis Revival
themes.historicalContext: 1980s resurgence of Memphis aesthetics in fashion and graphic design.

themes.name: Retro-Futurism
themes.historicalContext: 1980s aesthetic reimagining early 20th-century futurism through contemporary lens.

themes.name: Grunge Design
themes.historicalContext: 1990s aesthetic from Seattle music scene. Reaction against polished design.
themes.tagline: Perfect imperfection in the digital age

themes.name: Supergraphics
themes.historicalContext: 1970s architectural trend using massive graphics to transform spaces.
themes.tagline: Architecture as a giant graphic statement

themes.name: California New Wave
themes.historicalContext: 1980s West Coast design movement blending surf culture with New Wave typography.
themes.tagline: Punk goes surfing in the neon sunset

themes.name: Postmodern Architecture
themes.historicalContext: 1970s-1990s reaction against modernism. Led by Robert Venturi and Michael Graves.
themes.tagline: Less is a bore - more is more

themes.name: Memphis Digital
themes.historicalContext: 1990s digital adaptation of Memphis aesthetics for early web design.

themes.name: Anti-Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: Conceptual movement (1980s) critiquing beauty standards in art/design.

themes.name: Digital Punk
themes.historicalContext: 1990s fusion of punk aesthetics with early digital tools like Photoshop 1.0.
themes.tagline: Fight the system with pixels and attitude

categories.title: Digital Revolution (1990-2010)
categories.description: Design approaches born from the transition to digital technology and early internet culture

themes.name: Skeuomorphic Design
themes.historicalContext: Dominant UI style (2000-2010) where digital interfaces mimicked physical objects. Pioneered by Apple under Steve Jobs.
themes.tagline: Digital interfaces dressed in physical clothing

themes.name: Web 1.0 Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: Early internet design (1991-1999) characterized by basic HTML and limited styling.
themes.tagline: The digital frontier in its purest form

themes.name: Flash Era Design
themes.historicalContext: Dominant web aesthetic (1996-2010) powered by Adobe Flash. Enabled animations and interactivity.
themes.tagline: Where the web learned to move

themes.name: Y2K Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: Millennium-era design (1997-2003) reflecting digital optimism and Y2K anxiety.

themes.name: Web 2.0 Design
themes.historicalContext: Mid-2000s aesthetic (2004-2010) emphasizing user-generated content and social features.

themes.name: Pixel Art
themes.historicalContext: Digital art style (1980s-present) rooted in early computer and video game graphics.
themes.tagline: Digital art at its most fundamental

themes.name: Grunge Web Design
themes.historicalContext: 1990s-2000s web aesthetic influenced by grunge music and zine culture.

themes.name: Cyberpunk UI
themes.historicalContext: 1990s digital aesthetic inspired by William Gibson's novels and early cyberculture.
themes.tagline: The street finds its own uses for technology

themes.name: Glitch Art
themes.historicalContext: Emerging in the 2000s as artists intentionally corrupted digital files for aesthetic effect.

themes.name: Vaporwave
themes.historicalContext: Early 2010s internet microgenre blending 1990s nostalgia with surreal capitalism critique.
themes.tagline: A eulogy for the digital childhood we never had

themes.name: Seapunk
themes.historicalContext: 2011-2013 internet subculture merging oceanic themes with digital aesthetics.

themes.name: Tumblr Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: 2007-2014 microculture on Tumblr blending photography, GIFs, and text posts.

themes.name: Emoji Design
themes.historicalContext: Originating in Japan (1999), became global visual language by late 2000s.

themes.name: Flash Games Aesthetic
themes.historicalContext: 2000-2010 browser-based games using Adobe Flash, defining early internet gaming culture.
themes.tagline: Where the internet learned to play

themes.name: Early Social Media UI
themes.historicalContext: 2003-2008 platforms like MySpace and Friendster that pioneered social networking.

themes.name: Brutalist Web Design
themes.historicalContext: Mid-2010s reaction against polished corporate web design, emphasizing raw HTML.

themes.name: Mobile-First UI
themes.historicalContext: Emerging post-2007 with iPhone, prioritizing touch interfaces and responsive design.
themes.tagline: Design for the device in your pocket

themes.name: Indie Web Design
themes.historicalContext: 2010s movement promoting personal websites over corporate social platforms.
themes.tagline: Reclaim your corner of the internet

categories.title: Contemporary UI Design (2010-Present)
categories.description: Post-2010 interface paradigms defined by mobile-first approaches, design systems, and evolving digital aesthetics.

themes.name: Material Design
themes.historicalContext: Launched by Google in 2014 as 'Quantum Paper', combining tactile realism with digital flexibility.

themes.name: Flat Design
themes.historicalContext: Popularized by Microsoft's Metro UI (2010) and iOS 7 (2013), rejecting skeuomorphic textures.

themes.name: Neumorphism
themes.historicalContext: Emerging in 2019 from Dribbble trends, combining skeuomorphic depth with flat design minimalism.

themes.name: Glassmorphism
themes.historicalContext: Revived by macOS Big Sur (2020) using advanced GPU blur effects, evolving from Windows Vista's Aero.

themes.name: Brutalist Web
themes.historicalContext: Emerging circa 2015 as reaction to corporate design systems, championed by independent developers.

themes.name: Dark Mode Aesthetics
themes.historicalContext: Systematized by iOS 13 (2019) and Android 10 (2019), evolving from developer IDE preferences.
keyCharacteristics: True black or deep gray backgrounds

themes.name: Card-Based Architecture
themes.historicalContext: Popularized by Pinterest (2011) and Twitter (2012), adapting print editorial layouts to digital.

themes.name: Gradients 2.0
themes.historicalContext: Reintroduced by Instagram's 2016 rebrand, evolving from 2000s Web 2.0 gradients with CSS3 capabilities.

themes.name: Neobrutalism
themes.historicalContext: Emerging in 2019 as a Dribbble trend, reviving Brutalist principles with modern constraints.

themes.name: Claymorphism
themes.historicalContext: Popularized by Figma community in 2021 as a 3D evolution of Neumorphism.

themes.name: Scrollytelling
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by NYT's 'Snow Fall' (2012), evolving into commercial frameworks like ScrollMagic.

themes.name: Biometric Authentication UI
themes.historicalContext: Standardized by Apple Face ID (2017) and Android BiometricPrompt API.

themes.name: Emotional AI Interfaces
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by Affectiva (2016) and Microsoft's Emotion API, merging psychology with HCI.

themes.name: Retro-Skeuomorphism
themes.historicalContext: Revived by Notion (2020) and Apple's Big Sur icons, blending nostalgia with modern aesthetics.

themes.name: Hyperpersonalization UI
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by Spotify (2018) and Netflix, using ML to create unique interfaces per user.

themes.name: Immersive 3D UI
themes.historicalContext: Enabled by Three.js (2010) and react-three-fiber, bringing game engine techniques to the web.

themes.name: Holographic Interfaces
themes.historicalContext: Pioneered by Looking Glass Factory (2018) and Microsoft HoloLens, blending AR with volumetric displays.
